awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: SISIE: South Island, New Zealand, Subduction Initiation Experiment
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, scientists from the California Institute of Technology and The University of Texas at Austin will conduct an experiment south of New Zealand to investigate key unknowns about how plate tectonics works. Plate tectonics describes how the surface of the earth moves and has been very successful providing an understanding of the occurrence of most earthquakes and volcanic eruptions on the surface of Earth. One of the key aspects of plate tectonics is subduction when the cold plate (which is relatively dense) dips beneath another. A puzzling element of this is that new subduction zones must start where none existed in the past. The purpose of this project is to understand how a new subduction zone starts. The region selected for this study is the only known location on Earth where we can see a new subduction zone. The first target of study is the Australian plate as it first dives into Earth's interior. The second target is the new fault that defines the boundary between the Australian and the Pacific plates. All of the data collected will be integrated into a dynamic model of the formation of a new subduction zone and how the forces operate and change. Students from both the University of Texas and the California Institute of Technology will get valuable experience at sea learning about data collection, computational techniques, and data interpretation. New Zealand scientists will conduct onshore seismic recordings on the nature of the over-riding plate concurrent with this experiment. 



The project is an integrated, active-source seismic experiment on the Puysegur-Fiordland boundary south of South Island of New Zealand. The study will test the hypothesis that this type-example of incipient subduction is making a transition from a forced to a self-sustaining state. The project was motivated to understand the forces that drive subduction, specifically by models that suggest that during subduction initiation there is a fundamental transition from far-field plate stresses to the negative buoyancy of the slab. The subduction zone selected is a segment of the Macquarie Ridge Complex (the boundary between the Australian and Pacific plates), and is likely the best margin globally to study the early stages of subduction. The team will address several fundamental questions including: What controls the transition from a forced to self-sustaining state during subduction initiation? And, what are the mechanical conditions of the oceanic plate during incipient subduction? The PIs will test the hypothesize that a strengthening of the slab pull force causes the subsidence along the ridge. This plate tectonic scenario will be addressed with refined gravity models of the Puysegur region and seismic constraints on the crustal structure and sedimentary basin history. Moreover, initially steep fracture zones and normal faults transition or evolve to shallow thrust planes during subduction initiation, key aspects of the geodynamics. The project is guided by forward modeling of the seismic source-receiver configuration that shows that the dip and other features of the slab at two positions along strike, each with a different degree of compression, will be resolvable with the seismic methods employed.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: University of Texas Institute for Geophysics

por.por_cntn:
The South Island New Zealand Subduction Initiation Experiment (SISIE) is a marine geophysical study of Puysegur Trench, south of New Zealand. Beneath this trench lies one of the youngest subduction zones in the world. The purpose of the project is to investigate how the convergence between the Australian and Pacific plates has progressed from laterally forced underthrusting of the Australian Plate to self-sustaining subduction over the last 10 million years. The team of scientists gathered seismic reflection and refraction data as well as bathymetry, gravity and magnetic data on the R/V Marcus Langseth (cruise MGL1803) in February and March 2018. Eight marine seismic reflection lines parallel and across the Puysegur margin, with a total length of 1250 km, show the relief on crystalline basement, fault structures and sediment stratigraphy. The SISIE science team also collected two seismic refraction lines with ocean-bottom seismometers from the University of Texas. The wide-angle refraction data imaged the deep crustal structure of the southern and northern Puysegur margin from the surface to the base of the crust.

For several years, scientists have tried to explain the formation of a new subduction zone by either one of two models: 1) Lateral compression between two plates can induce underthrusting that becomes sustainable when one of the plates sinks into the deeper mantle, or 2) a gravitational instability causes the edge of a lithospheric plate to descend into the deeper mantle. The first mechanism would result in a compression phase in the overriding plate, followed by extension, whereas the second mode of subduction initiation only causes extension in the upper plate.

The first important scientific result derived from the new geophysical data gathered during the SISIE ship cruise was the discovery of a rifted continental margin in the Solander Basin, on the southwestern continental margin of New Zealand. This observation helps explain why the Australian oceanic lithosphere was first underthrust along this portion of the plate boundary, because the oceanic lithosphere is less buoyant than the continental crust of the Australian plate. Secondly, faults through the crust and sediments of the Solander basin show offsets that indicate shortening (compression) and extension at different geological times over the last 10 million years. Compression was most intense in the north, and this lateral compression between the Pacific and Australian plates propagated southward over the course of millions of years. These new SISIE data further indicate that convergence at the northern Puysegur trench has become self-sustaining due to the negative buoyancy of the downgoing mantle slab. As the subduction zone widened to the south, reduced friction at the plate boundary may have caused less deformation in the upper plate.

The SISIE project has helped train several graduate students in marine geology and geophysics, through instruction at sea on the R/V Marcus Langseth, and by using SISIE data for their dissertation research. During the SISIE cruise, the principal investigators taught courses for the students in bathymetry mapping seismology, gravity and magnetics. A graduate student at the University of Texas used data from the SISIE study for his dissertation.

 


Last Modified: 11/22/2021
Modified by: Harm J Van Avendonk
